Maybe I misunderstand Test Collectors -- point=

Your way to declare a test suite is already suppor=
ted by JUnit and a little cute refactoring.

Consider the AllTests pattern.=
 I can reduce it to a collection of AllTests or TestCase class names with a=
 little neat refactoring. Then I can use that little engine to store AllTes=
ts as text. The next step is to generate that text by doing a directory sca=
n. Now I have a TestSuite builder that build tests from a part of the file =
system.

I did nothing to change JUnit. I just decorated it. Does it belong=
 in the framework? I don't think so. That's a question of taste, in my opin=
ion.

So I think we understand each other quite well -- I just don't unders=
tand why you think this feature you suggest should be part of the framework=
? Why isn't it a candidate for JUnit-addons or something like that?

Rememb=
er that my goal -- Kent's goal, too -- is to keep JUnit very tight and smal=
l. It should provide just enough for everyone, rather than a glut of featur=
es that have limited use. The less to learn, the better. If you need more, =
grab add-on package X, add-on package Y and add-on package Z.

Also, the mo=
re magic in the package, the less the users need to learn to use it. I want=
